sub_topic: Using integration to find the work done by a force
message_1: A crate of mass 20 kg is pulled up a ramp that is 5 meters long and inclined at an angle of 30 degrees. A force of 100 N is applied to the crate to drag it up the ramp. Find the work done by the force in pulling the crate up the ramp.
message_2:
To find the work done by the force in pulling the crate up the ramp, we can use the formula:

Work = Force x Distance x cos(theta)

where Force is the applied force (100 N), Distance is the length of the ramp (5 meters), and theta is the angle between the force and the direction of motion (30 degrees).

First, we need to find the cosine of the angle:

cos(30) = 0.866

Now, we can plug the values into the formula:

Work = 100 N x 5 meters x 0.866

Work = 500 x 0.866

Work = 433 Nm

So, the work done by the force in pulling the crate up the ramp is 433 Nm (Newton meters).
